G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, because the matter in controversy exceeds $25,000.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in Suffolk County under G.L. c. 223, § 1, because the events giving rise to this claim occurred in Boston, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 90, \u00a7 14.proposition: Defendant breached that duty by opening his door without first ensuring that it was safe to do so, in violation of G.L. c. 90, § 14, which prohibits opening any vehicle door unless it is reasonably safe and can be done without interfering with other traffic.

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).proposition: Under Massachusetts common law, every motorist owes a duty to operate and park a vehicle with reasonable care to avoid foreseeable harm to others.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss motorists, motor vehicles, or any duty related to operating or parking vehicles. It addresses a property owner/general contractor’s potential liability for injuries from collapsing scaffolding and focuses on duty, control, and causation in that construction context. Because the case nowhere articulates a general duty of motorists to operate or park vehicles with reasonable care, it does not support the stated proposition.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).relevant_excerpt: With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 (1965); J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 204 (2d ed. 1989).

Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth., 905 F.2d.raw_text: Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth., 905 F.2d 515 (1st Cir. 1990)
Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth., 905 F.2d.proposition: Under Massachusetts common law, every motorist owes a duty to operate and park a vehicle with reasonable care to avoid foreseeable harm to others.
Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth., 905 F.2d.case_name: Lisa Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Authority, Appeal of Donald Hertzfeldt and Peter Langley
Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth., 905 F.2d.support_reasoning: The opinion is about recoverability of reputation damages in an ordinary negligence action, not about the scope of a motorist’s duty in operating or parking a vehicle. The only general negligence discussion is about elements like duty, breach, and proximate cause, without articulating any Massachusetts rule that every motorist must operate and park with reasonable care to avoid foreseeable harm. Thus, this case does not establish or discuss the specific Massachusetts common-law duty of motorists claimed in the proposition.
Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth., 905 F.2d.relevant_excerpt: "In any negligence cause of action, there are four elements on which plaintiffs must adduce adequate evidence to prevail. Plaintiffs must show: (1) a legal duty owed by defendant to plaintiff; (2) a breach of that duty; (3) proximate or legal cause; and (4) actual damage or injury. See W. Prosser & W. Keeton, The Law of Torts Sec. 30 (5th ed. 1985); see also Quinones, 492 F.2d at 1274."

Breen v. Burns, 280 Mass. 222 (1932).proposition: Defendant’s conduct violated G.L. c. 90, § 14, which itself provides evidence of negligence under Breen v. Burns, 280 Mass. 222 (1932), and Guinan v. Famous Players-Lasky Corp., 267 Mass. 501 (1929).
Breen v. Burns, 280 Mass. 222 (1932).support_reasoning: Breen v. Burns is a probate/limitations case about funeral expenses and which statute of limitations (G.L. c. 197, § 9 vs. G.L. c. 260, § 11) governs actions against an estate. It does not involve motor vehicle operation, G.L. c. 90, § 14, or negligence standards at all, and therefore cannot stand for the proposition that a violation of c. 90, § 14 is evidence of negligence. The citation to Breen v. Burns for that negligence proposition is inaccurate or misplaced.
Breen v. Burns, 280 Mass. 222 (1932).relevant_excerpt: For reasons hereinafter stated the applicable statute of limitations is G. L. c. 197, § 9, which provides that an “administrator, after having given due notice of his appointment, shall not be held to answer to an action by a creditor of the deceased which is not commenced within one year from the time of his giving bond . . . with exceptions not here material, rather than G. L. c. 260, § 11….”

Guinan v. Famous Players-Lasky Corp., 26.raw_text: Guinan v. Famous Players-Lasky Corp., 267 Mass. 501 (1929)
Guinan v. Famous Players-Lasky Corp., 26.proposition: Defendant’s conduct violated G.L. c. 90, § 14, which itself provides evidence of negligence under Breen v. Burns, 280 Mass. 222 (1932), and Guinan v. Famous Players-Lasky Corp., 267 Mass. 501 (1929).
Guinan v. Famous Players-Lasky Corp., 26.support_reasoning: The proposition speaks about a violation of G.L. c. 90, § 14 (a motor vehicle statute) being evidence of negligence. Guinan involves scrap motion picture film given in burlap bags, a subway car fire, and violation of fire prevention regulations—not any motor vehicle operation or G.L. c. 90, § 14. The court holds that violation of the fire marshal’s film regulations is evidence of negligence, but it neither cites nor interprets G.L. c. 90, § 14, so it cannot be authority for that specific statutory point.
Guinan v. Famous Players-Lasky Corp., 26.relevant_excerpt: “The regulations have the force and effect of law. A violation of a statute, ordinance or regulation, although not conclusive, is evidence of negligence on the part of a violator as to all consequences that the statute, ordinance or regulation was intended to prevent. Wright v. Malden & Melrose Railroad, 4 Allen, 283, 290. Lane v. Atlantic Works, 111 Mass. 136, 140. … Gordon v. Bedard, 265 Mass. 408, 411.”

Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Authority.raw_text: Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Authority, 376 Mass. 101 (1978)
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Authority.proposition: Plaintiff’s injuries were a direct and foreseeable consequence of Defendant’s negligence within the meaning of Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Authority, 376 Mass. 101 (1978).
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Authority.support_reasoning: The opinion directly addresses causation and foreseeability, holding that the jury could find the Authority’s negligence in failing to secure the forklift was a culpable and direct cause of plaintiff’s injury, and that the intoxicated seaman’s intervening conduct was foreseeable and did not break the causal chain. Thus, Jesionek stands for the proposition that plaintiff’s injuries were a direct and foreseeable consequence of defendant’s negligence under these circumstances.
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Authority.relevant_excerpt: “The general rule is that ‘[t]he act of a third person, intervening and contributing a condition necessary to the injurious effect of the original negligence, will not excuse the first wrongdoer, if such act ought to have been foreseen. The original negligence still remains a culpable and direct cause of the injury.’ … Under the facts of this case the jury would have been warranted in concluding that the actions of the seaman were foreseeable… Consequently, a jury could have found that the plaintiff’s injury was caused by a negligent act for which the authority was responsible.”

Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..proposition: Defendant’s actions constitute negligence under Massachusetts law as recognized in Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47 (1983) (duty arises from foreseeability of risk), Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401 (1991) (breach established where conduct fails reasonable person standard), and Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc., 423 Mass. 637 (1996) (proximate causation requires only foreseeability of harm).
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..support_reasoning: This excerpt is a dissent that turns entirely on lack of proximate causation and the speculative nature of the evidence; it does not discuss the existence of a duty arising from foreseeability or the general negligence standards cited in Mullins, Ulwick, or Poskus. The dissent repeatedly assumes negligence arguendo but concludes that causation and foreseeability of this particular harm were not sufficiently shown. Thus, this passage does not provide affirmative authority for the broad propositions about duty, breach, or proximate cause that it is being cited to support.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff had the burden of proving ‘that the defendant[s] took a risk with respect to the plaintiff’s safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk.’ Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323, 330 (1982). Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 454 (1969). … Rape was not within the foreseeable risk of failure to lock the refectory.”

Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401 (.proposition: Defendant’s actions constitute negligence under Massachusetts law as recognized in Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47 (1983) (duty arises from foreseeability of risk), Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401 (1991) (breach established where conduct fails reasonable person standard), and Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc., 423 Mass. 637 (1996) (proximate causation requires only foreseeability of harm).
Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401 (.support_reasoning: Ulwick does not articulate a general rule that ‘breach is established where conduct fails the reasonable person standard.’ Instead, the court holds no common‑law duty exists for a social host who neither serves nor supplies alcohol, and therefore there can be no negligence liability at all. The discussion of negligence elements appears only to emphasize that, absent a duty, statutory violations do not create a civil cause of action; Ulwick does not function as authority defining when breach is established under the reasonable person standard.
Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401 (.relevant_excerpt: “Any liability on the defendant's part in such a situation must be grounded in the common law of negligence… meaning that the plaintiff has the burden of proving each and every element of that claim: duty, breach of duty (or, the element of negligence), causation (actual and proximate) and damages… It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se…. Since no common law duty exists here, it follows that the statutes relied on by the plaintiff do not of themselves create a cause of action in tort.”

Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.raw_text: Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc., 423 Mass. 637 (1996)
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.proposition: Defendant’s actions constitute negligence under Massachusetts law as recognized in Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47 (1983) (duty arises from foreseeability of risk), Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401 (1991) (breach established where conduct fails reasonable person standard), and Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc., 423 Mass. 637 (1996) (proximate causation requires only foreseeability of harm).
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.support_reasoning: The quoted concurrence from Poskus does not state that proximate causation requires only foreseeability of harm; it expressly focuses on whether the plaintiff’s injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm and disputes the majority’s broader view of causation. It does not purport to redefine or expand causation generally, and in fact criticizes the majority’s treatment of earlier causation cases. Thus, using Poskus as authority for the broad proposition that proximate causation requires only foreseeability of harm overstates and mischaracterizes the case.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.relevant_excerpt: “I cannot join this conclusion. This view of causation is not mine as is evidenced by the fact that the decisions relied on by the court as enunciating this view were, with one exception, rendered without my acquiescence. I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiffs injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Plaintiff’s comparative negligence, if any, was less than that of Defendant, and thus Plaintiff is entitled to recovery pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 85 (comparative negligence statute).

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 6B and 6C.proposition: Award interest and costs pursuant to G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B and 6C;
